abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Adaptable Program
            Loan for the Urban Flood Prevention and Drainage Project for
            Argentina were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: for complicated works that are new to a country or
            sector, robust background analysis is crucial to a
            high-quality outcome, and can require a feasibility analysis
            as part of a separate project. A combination of structural
            and non-structural measures is a necessary but challenging
            feature of integrated flood management projects, which
            requires specific implementation arrangements to incentivize
            the prioritization of both dimensions. Approaches to
            providing cost contingencies should be tailored to specific
            economic and project contexts. Restructuring should be
            proactively used during implementation to address weaknesses
            in the results framework, particularly addressing weak or
            poorly designed indicators. Pre-emptive action should be
            taken by project teams to identify potential for
            institutional friction between local and national government
            levels, which should be addressed prior to approval to
            minimize consequences on implementation.
